messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "Scott Stirling" <scottstirling@...>
>
> I think this post is pretty offtopic. But, you used the word "Agile," so,
I
> read it and am replying.
>
> Interesting article thoughts. Also quite "high level" and speculative,
> which made me wonder about some facts.

Yes it is, and I too am replying. I work for a large company that has
offices in Israel, Belgium, Canada, the US, and various other locales around
the world. Many of these places have development teams, some of them sharing
development tasks on the same projects. A lot of large companies that have a
worldwide presence also have their development efforts spread out around the
world. Also, the Open Source movement seems to have a widespread community.
I don't know that outsourcing is that much different with respect to
efficiency/comminication/etc. compared to other forms of geographically
disparate development teams.

There are of course problems with communication/etc. - but somehow the job
still gets done and I haven't seen a huge mass exodus from the US of
development jobs despite the fact that some very big names have been
predicting such a trend for over a decade. What I wonder is, what are the
core objections to outsourcing? Do people object to:

1) The fact that some people around the world will work for less than they
do? If so, get used to it - welcome to the new world. I welcome and applaud
competition. When I was unemployed I actively let employers know I was
willing to underbid just about anybody because the alternative was being
unemployed.

2) The fact that these people may not engender the kind of loyalty we get
from our employers? If so, get real; just ask any of the thousands of
unemployed Java developers how loyal and concerned their former employers
were.

3) Responsiblity? Concerned about the conditions in a third world country
not being as good as in the US? Welcome to the real world. A programmer in
India is going to have better living conditions than 99% of the rest of the
populace, and by making a decent living wage for their locale (and probably
then some), they help the local economy and create other jobs by spending
thier wages. It is a tired axiom but generally true; as the tide rises, so
do all boats.

If outsourcing is such a bad idea, if there are problems that make it an
economically stupid thing to do, then eventually companies will discover
that fact or fail - just as many discovered they couldn't make money by
jumping on the internet bandwagon without a sound business plan.

FWIW,
LCB
